messages.user_message: What is the appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling (FDM) with polylactic acid (PLA) is generally in the range of 190–230 °C. The most commonly used range is 201–220 °C, with several studies indicating that the best mechanical properties for pure PLA prints are achieved at around 215 °C. It is important not to exceed 240 °C, as this can lead to polymer degradation. The optimal temperature can also depend on factors such as bed temperature, surrounding temperature, printing speed, and the thermal properties of the PLA being used. Experimental studies have shown that printing at 215 °C provides the best tensile performance for PLA parts, while lower temperatures may result in poor bonding between layers, and higher temperatures can affect dimensional stability and crystallinity due to excessive material flow and slow cooling rates [reference_188.pdf, p.784; reference_120.pdf, p.290].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling (FDM) with polylactic acid (PLA) is commonly around 90 mm/s. Experimental results indicate that an infill speed of 90 mm/s gave the highest Young's modulus for pure PLA, and this speed is considered optimal among the tested range (70 to 110 mm/s). Lower or higher speeds showed only slight differences in mechanical properties compared to 90 mm/s. Therefore, 90 mm/s is recommended as the most appropriate printing speed for pure PLA filament to achieve improved mechanical performance [reference_120.pdf].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling (FDM) with polylactic acid (PLA) depends on the desired surface quality and printing time. According to experimental results, a smaller layer height (such as 0.05 mm) results in a smoother surface finish, while a larger layer height (such as 0.25 mm) produces a rougher surface but reduces printing time. Therefore, if the goal is to achieve the best surface quality, a layer height of 0.05 mm is recommended. If faster printing is more important and a rougher surface is acceptable, a layer height of 0.25 mm can be used [reference_145.pdf, p.2].
